name: Kaunas
fun_fact: Fun fact: Kaunas was Lithuania's temporary capital from 1920-1939 when Vilnius was occupied. The city has Europe's only museum dedicated to devils (≈Ωmuidzinaviƒçius Museum) with over 3,000 devil figures. Kaunas was named European Capital of Culture 2022.

hero_dishes.name: Cepelinai
hero_dishes.description: Large potato dumplings shaped like zeppelins, stuffed with meat or curd cheese, served with sour cream and bacon bits
hero_dishes.origin_story: Named after the Zeppelin airships due to their shape, cepelinai are Lithuania's national dish. Created in the early 20th century, they combine grated and mashed potatoes formed around a meat filling. They're heavy, filling, and designed for cold Lithuanian winters. Eating one is a commitment - they're massive.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Traditional Lithuanian restaurants in Kaunas Old Town, Berneli≈≥ U≈æeiga (folk-style restaurant), or local eateries

hero_dishes.name: ≈†altibar≈°ƒçiai (Cold Beet Soup)
hero_dishes.description: Bright pink cold soup made with beets, kefir, cucumbers, dill, and hard-boiled eggs - refreshing and tangy
hero_dishes.origin_story: This vibrant pink soup is summer's answer to borscht. Made with beets, buttermilk or kefir, fresh cucumbers, and dill, it's served ice-cold. The color is shocking pink - Instagram-worthy before Instagram existed. Lithuanian grandmothers serve it on hot summer days. The sourness from fermented dairy is addictive.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Lithuanian restaurants throughout Kaunas, especially in summer months, or local bistros

hero_dishes.name: Kibinai
hero_dishes.description: Half-moon shaped pastries filled with mutton or pork, onions, and spices - flaky crust with savory filling
hero_dishes.origin_story: Brought to Lithuania by Karaite Jews from Crimea in the 14th century, kibinai became a Lithuanian staple. The Karaite community settled in Trakai (near Kaunas), and their meat pies spread throughout Lithuania. The crispy pastry shatters when bitten, releasing juicy meat filling.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Bakeries in Kaunas Old Town, or restaurants serving Lithuanian cuisine

hero_dishes.name: Bulviniai Blynai (Potato Pancakes)
hero_dishes.description: Crispy potato pancakes made from grated potatoes, eggs, and onions - served with sour cream
hero_dishes.origin_story: Like cepelinai, these show Lithuanian love for potatoes. Grated potatoes mixed with egg and onion, fried until golden and crispy. They're comfort food eaten year-round, often as a main dish rather than side. Simple, peasant food that became national identity.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Traditional Lithuanian restaurants, cafes in Kaunas, or market stalls

signature_drinks.name: Midus (Lithuanian Mead)
signature_drinks.description: Honey-based alcoholic drink, fermented with hops and spices - sweet, warming, ancient
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Midus is one of Europe's oldest alcoholic beverages, made in Lithuania for over 1,000 years. It's fermented honey water with hops, sometimes flavored with berries or spices. Served at room temperature or warm in winter. Lithuanians drink it at celebrations and festivals. The sweetness hides surprising alcohol strength.

signature_drinks.name: ≈†vyturys or Utenos Beer
signature_drinks.description: Lithuanian lagers - crisp, clean, perfect for washing down heavy potato dishes
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Lithuania has strong beer culture. ≈†vyturys (lighthouse) is the most popular brand. Locals drink it cold with cepelinai or kibinai - the crisp lager cuts through rich, heavy food. Beer gardens fill up in summer along the Nemunas River in Kaunas.
